body:
Whenever exceptions show in the console logs, they end up corrupted, with duplicated lines and so on.

This is definitely a problem we see in usability studies. It makes the messages really hard to understand.

comment_data.body: I don't think I've ever seen a message _not_ be corrupted. This should show it: create a new app, and then replace the contents of the Scafford's "body" with `new Column(children: [new ListView()])`.

I cannot repro this. I changed the body of Scaffold, and tried running both from IntelliJ and command prompt.

Output from the command prompt, messages 0-20:

I can through this on iOS and didn't see issues (but we should keep working to track this down).
Can you paste everything from the top double-line to the bottom double-line?

(and, I see a leading `══╡ `, but not a trailing one, if one is expected)
Compare that output to what happens when you do the same with `flutter run` on the command line to see what I mean.

@Hixie, I probably need to take a closer look, but the issue isn't jumping out at me...

Woah, you get corrupted data on the command line too? Fascinating. Can you elaborate on how you ran this so I can try to repro locally? I've never seen this outside of an IDE.

The corruption is, e.g., the duplication of `Vertical viewport was given unbounded height.`.
Yeah, let me sync w/ head and re-run this.

Ah! Maybe the problem is with MacOS, iOS, or the iOS Simulator?

Does it happen if you plug in an Android device?

Things look better in Android land:

```
I/flutter (20892): ══╡ EXCEPTION CAUGHT BY RENDERING LIBRARY ╞═════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
I/flutter (20892): The following assertion was thrown during performResize():
I/flutter (20892): Vertical viewport was given unbounded height.
I/flutter (20892): Viewports expand in the scrolling direction to fill their container.In this case, a vertical
I/flutter (20892): viewport was given an unlimited amount of vertical space in which to expand. This situation
I/flutter (20892): typically happens when a scrollable widget is nested inside another scrollable widget.
I/flutter (20892): If this widget is always nested in a scrollable widget there is no need to use a viewport because
I/flutter (20892): there will always be enough vertical space for the children. In this case, consider using a Column
I/flutter (20892): instead. Otherwise, consider using the "shrinkWrap" propery (or a ShrinkWrappingViewport) to size
I/flutter (20892): the height of the viewport to the sum of the heights of its children.
```

Weird!

I looked at the iOS logging code in flutter_tools but nothing obvious comes to mind. I wonder what's up!
This issue was moved to flutter/flutter#9790
